[[Category:mldonkey]] Be sure to change the [[max_hard_download_rate]] from the default value of 50 to something higher (1000, for example). You should also raise the [[max_hard_upload_rate]] from its default (10) to something higher as well (40, for example); apart from being the right thing to do, in general connecting clients will give you more data if you give them more data. In both cases the values for [[max_hard_download_rate]] and [[max_hard_upload_rate]] should be about 80 percent of the maximum downstream and upstream bandwidth provided by your link.
The default values for [[max_opened_connections]], [[max_connections_per_second]] and [[max_concurrent_downloads]] are probably all acceptable.

page.title: Blocking non-local senders for local-only recipients

revision.text:
[[Category:Sendmail]] [[Category:Email]] The → symbol (right-pointing arrow) is used to indicate a tab: 
LOCAL_CONFIG
F{Internal}/etc/mail/internal.only
LOCAL_RULESETS
SLocal_check_rcpt
R$*                      →$: <@> $>canonify $1
R<@> $={Internal}<@$=w.> →$: <$1@$2>
R<@> $={Internal}        →$: <$1@$j>
R<@>$+                   →$@ OK
R$*                      →$: $&{client_name}
R$@                      →$@ OK
R$*$=w                   →$@ OK
R$*                      →$#error $@ 5.7.1 $: 551 $&f not allowed to send to recipient
See [[combining rulesets]] for an example combining the functionality of this ruleset with another. = Efficacy = The following is a [[LogWatch]] sample taken from the [[wincent.com]] mail server during a 24 hour period in early July 2006 showing that the custom ruleset blocked approximately 178 incoming messages. = Efficacy =
== Efficacy of server-side spam blocking ==
The following results show the number of messages blocked (rejected or discarded) at the [[wincent.com]] mail server level in a typical 24 hour period due to the anti-spam technologies and techniques linked to from this page. They are not necessarily statistically valid samples, based on a very small data set collected during June and July of 2006, but they do provide some indication of the amount of spam which is being beaten at the server and never makes it through to the client.
* [[Automatically deleting high-scoring spam]]: 47 messages * [[Address migration]]: 142 messages * [[Blocking non-local senders for local-only recipients]]: 178 messages * [[DNS-based blacklisting]]: 261 messages * [[Virus filtering]]: 47 messsages (see [[ClamAV log sample]])
It is difficult to estimate the number of spam messages that is collectively being blocked by these countermeasures because they operate at different levels and were introduced incrementally. For example, [[DNS-based blacklisting]] was the last countermeasure to be introduced in the above list, and it blocks spam before it gets to any of the other countermeasures. As such, the number of messages stopped per day for the other countermeasures is reduced but that does not mean that their efficacy has diminished.
The order in which the techniques were deployed to the server is:
# [[Virus filtering]] # [[Automatically deleting high-scoring spam]] # [[Blocking non-local senders for local-only recipients]] # [[Address migration]] # [[DNS-based blacklisting]]
But the order in which the techniques are actually applied to incoming messages is:
# [[DNS-based blacklisting]] (connections rejected with 554 reply code) # [[Blocking non-local senders for local-only recipients]] (delivery aborted with 5.7.1/551 reply code) # [[Address migration]] ("User unknown" returned to spammer) # [[Virus filtering]] (message immediately deleted before arriving at mailbox) # [[Automatically deleting high-scoring spam]] (message immediately deleted before arriving at mailbox)
So as messages pass through the various lines of defense, the number of spam messages getting through to subsequent levels is successively reduced. [[DNS-based blacklisting]] is the numerically most important countermeasure, stopping the largest number of messages, and this means that subsequent levels have to defend against fewer spam messages.
== Efficacy of client-side filtering ==
The following results are from a test period of 24 hours in mid-July 2006:
* 62 [[spam]] messages made it through to my email client (two accounts: one business and one personal). * An additional 102 messages were received by the client during the same period, bringing the total count to 164 messages ([[spam]] and [[ham]]) in all. * 38% of all email received by the client was [[spam]] * Of the [[spam]] messages 25 were correctly tagged as [[spam]] by [[SpamAssassin]]. * The remaining 37 were not tagged by [[SpamAssassin]] (false negatives). * [[SpamAssassin]] did not produce any false positives. * [[SpamAsssassin]]'s accuracy at the client level during the test period was a disappointing 77.4%, but this number does not reflect the [[Automatically deleting high-scoring spam|high-scoring spam that was automatically deleted]] by [[SpamAssassin]] at the server level. * [[SpamSieve]] correctly identified all 62 spam messages as spam, with no false positives and no false negatives. * [[SpamSieve]]'s accuracy during the test period was a perfect 100%.
These results show that the new server-level measures have had a significant impact on the number of spam messages reaching the client. Prior to implementing the measures the average spam count (the average of spam messages received at the client level per day) was steadily climbing and had reached over 170 spam messages per day. The [http://wincent.com/a/about/wincent/weblog/archives/2005/11/spamsieve_one_y.php oldest stats that I have available] are for a one year period between November 2004 and November 2005 in which I had received an average of about 40 spam messages per day and 11% of all email I received was spam. Today (mid-July 2006) the cumulative average is 75 spam messages per day and 22% of all email I've received has been spam. It seems likely that this proportion can only increase from here given that on the day of the test 38% of all mail received by the client was spam, approaching the average of 50% [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/16/AR2006051601873.html?referrer=email&referrer=email claimed by Symantec].
So these statistics show that the volume of [[spam]] attacks has spectacularly increased but that the new server-level measures have been effective in curbing their impact.
= Areas for improvement =
The [[SpamAssassin]] accuracy figures are disappointing despite using [[SpamAssassin Bayesian filtering|Bayesian training]] followed by weeks of corrective training. I will continue the corrective training in the hope that accuracy improves. If the accuracy improves sufficiently then I may be able to consider lowering the threshold for [[automatically deleting high-scoring spam]].
Of the 62 spam messages received at the client, 19 were directed to postmaster addresses and these unfortunately cannot be blocked due to [[RFC 2821]].
8 were sent to my personal account, 32 were sent to my business account, and the remaining had headers that were so munged that it was not easy to discern the original recipient address.
In the future I may consider undertaking another [[address migration]], at least for my business account, as well as adding additional [[DNS-based blacklists]]. Another option is [[grey-listing]], but I am hesitant to use it given that in many cases I rely on the near-instantaneous nature of email.

[[Category:Sendmail]] [[Category:Email]] This example shows how to add a [[DNS-based blacklist]] to the [[sendmail]] configuration file. In this case the SBL-XBL list provided by [[Spamhaus]], one of the most reputable and accurate blacklists, is used for the purposes of illustration. 
FEATURE(`dnsbl',`sbl-xbl.spamhaus.org',`"554 Rejected " $&{client_addr} " - see http://www.spamhaus.org/ then contact " $&{postmaster_addr}')dnl
To minimize the damage done in the unlikely event of obtaining a false positive the error message that is returned to the client includes the following elements: * A 554 error code (as described in [[RFC 821]]/[[RFC 2821]]). * The connecting IP address found in the blacklist. * A link to the [[Spamhaus]] website where the sender can find out what the blacklisting means, why it occurred, and how to be removed from the blacklist. * An alternative contact address of the form postmaster@[[example.com]] that can be used to inform the server administrator, bypassing [[DNS-based blacklist]] checks. This specification depends on a special ruleset that defines the postmaster_addr macro (see "[[Store postmaster address]]"), as well as the modification of the following line in the configuration file: 
dnl FEATURE(delay_checks)dnl
Which should be changed to: 
FEATURE(`delay_checks', `friend')dnl
After making these changes the [[Sendmail]] configuration should be rebuilt and the daemon restarted. Appropriate entries should be added to the /etc/mail/access file to ensure that delivery to the postmaster and abuse addresses is not blocked by the blacklist: 
Spam:abuse@	        →FRIEND
Spam:postmaster@	→FRIEND
To test that the blacklisting works correctly, messages can be sent to [mailto:nelson-sbl-test@crynwr.com nelson-sbl-test@crynwr.com] and [mailto:nelson-xbl-test@crynwr.com nelson-xbl-test@crynwr.com]. To test that the postmaster address is ''not'' being subjected to DNS-based blacklisting (a requirement of [[RFC 2821]]) you can connect via telnet from the server to be tested to: telnet://ns1.crynwr.com The telnet-based test will try sending mail to "postmaster@[[example.com]]", and should the messages should be accepted for delivery. = Efficacy = During a test period of 24 hours in mid-July 2006 on the [[wincent.com]] mail server the [[DNS-based blacklist]] described here stopped 261 connection attempts. For other efficacy statistics see [[combatting spam]]. = See also = * "Crynwr spam blocking resources": http://www.crynwr.com/spam/ * "postmaster.rfc-ignorant.org listing policy": http://rfc-ignorant.org/policy-postmaster.php * http://www.spamhaus.org/

[[Category:Sendmail]] To combine [[sendmail]] rulesets you would name them as subroutines and then call them. For example, to add the two subroutines, "[[Store_postmaster_address]]" and "[[Protect_internal_only]]", to the Local_check_rcpt ruleset you would do the following: 
LOCAL_RULESETS
SLocal_check_rcpt
R$*          →$: $1 $| $>"Store_postmaster_address" $1
R$* $| $#$*  →$#$2
R$*          →$: $1 $| $>"Protect_internal_only" $1
R$* $| $#$*  →$#$2

SStore_postmaster_address
# ... rules for the "Store_postmaster_address" subroutine appear here

SProtect_internal_only
# ... rules for the "Protect_internal_only" subroutine appear here
As always in [[sendmail]] configuration files, the → symbol (right-pointing arrow) indicates a tab. = Complete example = 
LOCAL_CONFIG
Kstorage macro
F{Internal}/etc/mail/internal.only
LOCAL_RULESETS
SStore_postmaster_address
R$*                           →$: $>canonify $1
R$* < @ $=w . >               →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@$2 $)
R$*                           →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@example.com $)
SProtect_internal_only
R$*                           →$: <@> $>canonify $1
R<@> $={Internal} < @ $=w . > →$: <$1@$2>
R<@> $={Internal}             →$: <$1@$j>
R<@> $+                       →$@ OK
R$*                           →$: $&{client_name}
R$@                           →$@ OK
R$*$=w                        →$@ OK
R$*                           →$#error $@ 5.7.1 $: 551 $&f not allowed to send to recipient
SLocal_check_rcpt
R$*                           →$: $1 $| $>"Store_postmaster_address" $1
R$* $| $#$*                   →$#$2
R$*                           →$: $1 $| $>"Protect_internal_only" $1
R$* $| $#$*                   →$#$2
= See also = http://www.sendmail.org/~ca/email/protected.html

[[Category:Sendmail]] The purpose of this custom ruleset is to extract the domain portion of the recipient address and use it as a basis for constructing a postmaster address of the form "postmaster@[[example.com]]". The address is then stored in the postmaster_addr macro and is available for use in other rulesets. = Configuration directives = 
LOCAL_CONFIG
Kstorage macro
LOCAL_RULESETS
SStore_postmaster_address
R$*             →$: $>canonify $1
R$* < @ $=w . > →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@$2 $)
R$*             →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@example.com $)
As always in [[sendmail]] configuration files, the → symbol (right-pointing arrow) symbol indicates a tab. See [[combining rulesets]] for an example that combines the functionality of this ruleset with another, and [[DNS-based blacklisting]] for an application of this ruleset. = Annotated version = 
LOCAL_CONFIG
Kstorage macro
The K indicates that this line is a key file declaration. Key file declarations follow this syntax: 
Kmapname mapclass arguments
The ''mapname'' is the handle by which the map is referenced in the rewriting rules. The ''mapclass'' indicates the type of the map, and the ''arguments'' vary according to the ''mapclass''. In the current example the ''mapname'' is storage and the ''mapclass'' is macro, which means that the map can be used to set or clear macro values. Key file declarations that use the macro ''mapclass'' take no arguments. 
LOCAL_RULESETS
SStore_postmaster_address
The initial S sets the current ruleset being collected to Store_postmaster_address. Labelling the ruleset like this is akin to creating a "subroutine". The subsequent lines begin with R indicating that they are rewriting rules. Each rewriting rule consists of a left-hand side (LHS) and a right-hand side (RHS), separated by a tab character (indicated here using the → symbol). Input passed into the ruleset is checked against the pattern in the LHS and if it matches then the input is rewritten as specified by the RHS. An optional third field, delimited by another tab, could be used for comments (ignored by [[Sendmail]]), but no comments are shown here. 
R$*             →$: $>canonify $1
Here the RHS matches against any input at all ($* matches zero or more tokens). The LHS has a $: prefix, which causes processing to continue to the next rule; this is necessary to avoid an infinite loop because normally rules that match are retried in a loop until they fail. The $> directive causes the remainder of the line to be evaluated and then passed to another ruleset, in this case the canonify ruleset which returns addresses in a standardized (canonified) form. The "remainder of the line" in this case is $1 which is equivalent to the first token matched on the RHS (in this case, the entire input). 
R$* < @ $=w . > →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@$2 $)
Processing continues on this next line, where the RHS pattern will match "anything at all" ($*, or "zero or more tokens") followed by a left angle bracket (<), an "at" symbol (@) and any phrase in class w ($=w), where w is "the set of all names this host is known by", followed by a period (.), followed by a right angle bracket (>). This pattern will match addresses in canonical form because the canonify ruleset turns addresses like john@example.com into john < @ example . com . >. Note that although the patten includes whitespace, this is largely for readability and the whitespace will be ignored during pattern matching. The username part of the address will be captured into $1 and the hostname part will be captured into $2 for use on the RHS of the rule. The RHS sets the postmaster_addr macro. The initial $@ prefix causes the ruleset to return with the remainder of the RHS as the value. The postmaster_addr macro is set using the value passed as the first argument in the map lookup. The map itself returns an empty string. The syntax for referencing maps is: 
$(map key $@ arguments $: default $)
In the current example the ''map'' is the storage map declared previously, the ''key'' is postmaster_addr, the $@ introduces the argument list, which in this case contains only one element, postmaster@$2 where $2 will be expanded to the host name of the recipient email address. In the current example there is no ''default'' value and the default value marker ($:) is omitted. 
R$*             →$@ $(storage {postmaster_addr} $@ postmaster@example.com $)
This last rule is processed in the case where the previous rule did not match, as would be the case if the recipient address did not match any of the local names by which the mail server is known. In this case the RHS matches anything at all ($*, or "zero or more tokens") and the LHS stores a default value in the postmaster_addr macro (in this case, postmaster@example.com). As is habitual, [[example.com]] is used here for the purposes of illustration only. = See also = http://www.sendmail.org/~ca/email/doc8.12/op-sh-5.html

[[Category:Ruby updates]] [[Category:Ruby 1.8.4]] [[Category:Tiger]] = Note = These notes are superseded by the article, "[[Building and installing Ruby 1.8.5 on Mac OS X Tiger]]". = Build = First, download, extract, configure and build: 
wget ftp://ftp.ruby-lang.org/pub/ruby/ruby-1.8.4.tar.gz
tar zxvf ruby-1.8.4.tar.gz 
cd ruby-1.8.4/
./configure 
make
Second, run the tests and install. Note that the full test suite (make check) can only be run ''after'' installing: 
make test
sudo make install
make check
Print out the version of the newly installed ruby interpreter: 
/usr/local/bin/ruby -v

[[Category:Ruby]] [[Category:Rails]] [[Ruby on Rails]] is a web application stack written in [[Ruby]] with a focus on "convention over configuration", testing, and rapid application development.
It will be included in [[Mac OS X]] [[Leopard]].
= Official site =
http://www.rubyonrails.org/
= See also =
* "Capistrano: Automating Application Deployment": http://manuals.rubyonrails.com/read/book/17 * "Really Getting Started in Rails": http://www.slash7.com/articles/2005/01/24/really-getting-started-in-rails * "How to show Google's Web Accelerator the door in Rails": http://david.backpackit.com/pub/37983 * "Skinny Controller, Fat Model", an excellent article that argues for and uses code examples to demonstrate keeping code out of views, simplifying controls, and letting models do the heavy lifting in the interests of better readability, maintainability and correctness: http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2006/10/18/skinny-controller-fat-model

[[Category:Ruby]] [[Ruby]] is an interpreted, object-oriented scripting language that is often compared to [[Python]] and [[Smalltalk]]. It has a very "pure" object model in the sense that ''everything'' is an object, even literal values like <tt>1</tt>, <tt>2</tt> and <tt>3</tt>, and values such as <tt>nil</tt>, <tt>true</tt> and <tt>false</tt>.
It features a very clean syntax which is light on punctuation and often offers various forms of expressing the same construct, which enables you to select the clearest option in a given circumstance and produce very readable (and therefore maintainable) code.
It has been very popular for some time in Japan, and recently has enjoyed increasing popularity elsewhere, partly driven by the interest in [[Ruby on Rails]]. A [[Ruby]] to [[Cocoa]] bridge will be shipped by [[Apple]] with the next version of [[Mac OS X]], [[Leopard]].
It's my scripting language of choice. My largest project to date in Ruby is [[Walrus]].

[[Category:Rails]] [[Category:Tiger]] To install [[Ruby on Rails]] using [[RubyGems]], the standard PATH environment variable must be overridden to ensure that the custom local copy of [[Ruby]] (version 1.8.4) is used instead of the default system install (version 1.8.2). The first step is to look at the current PATH setting: 
echo $PATH
The output should be similar to: 
/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/Users/wincent/bin:/usr/local/bin:/Developer/Tools:/usr/X11R6/bin:/usr/local/mysql/bin
Set the new PATH value, rearranging the order so that /usr/local/bin appears first in the list: 
PATH=/usr/local/bin:/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/Users/wincent/bin:/Developer/Tools:/usr/X11R6/bin:/usr/local/mysql/bin
Confirm that the order is correct: 
echo $PATH
The output should resemble this: 
/usr/local/bin:/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/Users/wincent/bin:/Developer/Tools:/usr/X11R6/bin:/usr/local/mysql/bin
Go ahead with the [[Ruby on Rails]] install: 
sudo gem install rails --include-dependencies
= Installation transcript = 
Bulk updating Gem source index for: http://gems.rubyforge.org
Successfully installed rails-1.1.4
Successfully installed rake-0.7.1
Successfully installed activesupport-1.3.1
Successfully installed activerecord-1.14.3
Successfully installed actionpack-1.12.3
Successfully installed actionmailer-1.2.3
Successfully installed actionwebservice-1.1.4
Installing ri documentation for rake-0.7.1...
Installing ri documentation for activesupport-1.3.1...
Installing ri documentation for activerecord-1.14.3...
Installing ri documentation for actionpack-1.12.3...
Installing ri documentation for actionmailer-1.2.3...
Installing ri documentation for actionwebservice-1.1.4...

Installing RDoc documentation for actionmailer-1.2.3...
Installing RDoc documentation for actionwebservice-1.1.4...
= Setting up the environment = For [[Rails]] to actually work you'll need to make changes to your PATH and RUBYLIB environment variables. I have the following in my ~/.bash_profile for this purpose: 
# /usr/local/bin has to come first so that custom Ruby install will be used (1.8.4)
PATH=/usr/local/bin:$PATH:$HOME/bin:/Developer/Tools:/usr/X11R6/bin
PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/mysql/bin
export PATH

# for Ruby on Rails
RUBYLIB="/usr/local/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8:/usr/local/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/i686-darwin8.7.1:/usr/local/lib/ruby/1.8:/usr/local/lib
/ruby/1.8/i686-darwin8.7.1"
export RUBYLIB
== Update: RUBYLIB with Mac OS X 10.4.8 == I later (March 2007) found that this RUBYLIB export prevented my new [[Ruby 1.8.6]] install from working and removed it from my .bash_profile. See "[[Building and installing Ruby 1.8.6 on Mac OS X Tiger]]" for more information. = See also = * [[Building and installing Ruby 1.8.4 on Mac OS X Tiger]] * [[Building and installing RubyGems 0.9.0 on Mac OS X Tiger]] * [[Installing Ruby on Rails 1.1.4 on Red Hat Enterprise Linux ES 3]] * [[Installing Ruby on Rails]] = An alternative approach = http://hivelogic.com/articles/2005/12/01/ruby_rails_lighttpd_mysql_tiger Using the already downloaded archives: 
tar zxvf readline-5.1.tar.gz 
cd readline-5.1/
./configure
make
sudo make install

tar zxvf ruby-1.8.4.tar.gz 
cd ruby-1.8.4/
./configure --enable-pthread --with-readline-dir=/usr/local
make
sudo make install
make check
When I try to follow those instructions I get a failure during sudo make check step: 
  1) Failure:
test_delete(TestDBM) [./dbm/test_dbm.rb:332]:
 exception expected but none was thrown.

  2) Failure:
test_s_open_error(TestSDBM) [./sdbm/test_sdbm.rb:123]:
 exception expected but none was thrown.

1313 tests, 14455 assertions, 2 failures, 0 errors
make: *** [test-all] Error 1
But not when doing a make check (without sudo): 
1313 tests, 14456 assertions, 0 failures, 0 errors
Then: 
sudo /usr/local/bin/ruby setup.rb
And I get this error: 
Bulk updating Gem source index for: http://gems.rubyforge.org
ERROR:  While executing gem ... (ArgumentError)
    syntax error on line 153073, col 20: `

Which is the same error as I was getting before when trying to do any remote operations with gem. Funnily enough this was working a few days ago. Now neither my hand-installed copy of RubyGems nor the version bundled with [[Locomotive]] works. Curiously, running sudo gem update fixed all of these warnings: 
sudo gem update
sudo gem install rails --include-dependencies
sudo gem install sqlite3-ruby
Note, however, that I still can't run any unit tests: 
script/generate model User
ruby test/unit/user_test.rb
Produces:

The database file does exist (created manually using sqlite3 db/test.sqlite3 and .schema to force changes to be flushed to disk) and the config/database.yml file contains this:

If I change:

To:

In test/test_helper.rb then I get a different error: 
Loaded suite test/unit/user_test
Started

test_truth(UserTest):
ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: SQLite3::SQLException: no such table: users: DELETE FROM users WHERE 1=1

page.title: Using SQLite for Ruby on Rails development on Mac OS X Tiger

revision.text:
[[Category:Rails]] [[Category:Mac OS X]] [[Category:Tiger]] = Configuration file = Change your config/database.yml file from: 
development:
  adapter: mysql
  database: DatabaseName_development
  username: root
  password:
  host: localhost

# Warning: The database defined as 'test' will be erased and
# re-generated from your development database when you run 'rake'.
# Do not set this db to the same as development or production.
test:
  adapter: mysql
  database: DatabaseName_test
  username: root
  password:
  host: localhost

production:
  adapter: mysql
  database: DatabaseName_production
  username: root
  password: 
  host: localhost
To: 
development:
  adapter: sqlite3
  dbfile: db/development.sqlite3

test:
  adapter: sqlite3
  dbfile: db/test.sqlite3

production:
  adapter: sqlite3
  dbfile: db/production.sqlite3
= Manual database creation = From a [[Rails]] application root: 
sqlite3 db/test.sqlite3
In order for the file to actually be created it appears that you must execute a command from within the [[SQLite]] interactive shell: 
.schema
.exit
Repeat this for the db/development.sqlite3 and db/production.sqlite3 databases. = Automatic database creation = See "[[First Ruby on Rails project on Mac OS X]]" for a demonstration of how to use [[rake]] to create databases and a new (empty) schema automatically. = See also = http://wiki.rubyonrails.org/rails/show/HowtoUseSQLite

page.title: First Ruby on Rails project on Mac OS X

revision.text:
[[Category:Ruby]] [[Category:Rails]] These notes were made while trying to put together my first ever [[Rails]] project. I recorded the steps taken so that it would be easier for me to repeat them in the future. I later expanded and improved upon these notes in "[[Rails application bootstrapping]]", and then went on to refine them further in "[[Behaviour-Driven Development with Rails]]". = Basic setup = # Install and run [[Locomotive]]. # Choose "Create New…" from the [[Locomotive]] "File" menu. # Choose "Edit in TextMate" from the "File" menu. # In the Terminal, change to your [[Rails]] project's application root. # Run command `locomotive bash-environment` to enable command line manipulation. # Set up your initial databases as described in "[[Using SQLite for Ruby on Rails development on Mac OS X Tiger]]"; skip over the "Manual database creation" step. = Creating your database files = # Create initial databases and an empty schema 
rake db_schema_dump
This will occur in the default (development) environment. Repeat for the other environments and then restore the RAILS_ENV to its original value. 
export RAILS_ENV=production
rake db_schema_dump
export RAILS_ENV=test
rake db_schema_dump
export RAILS_ENV=development
Alternatively using the env command: 
env RAILS_ENV=production rake db_schema_dump
env RAILS_ENV=test rake db_schema_dump
env RAILS_ENV=development rake db_schema_dump
# Creating your first table: One way of doing this: 
script/generate model wikis
This command actually creates the first migration file in db/migrate. From: 
class CreateWikis < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :wikis do |t|
      #t.column :name, :string
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :wikis
  end
end
To: 
class CreateWikis < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :wikis do |table|
      table.column :name, :string
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :wikis
  end
end
rake migrate
Adding columns to a table: 
script/generate migration weblogs
class Weblogs < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
  end

  def self.down
  end
end
class Weblogs < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :weblogs do |table|
      table.column :name, :string
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :weblogs
  end
end
rake migrate
== Keeping db/schema.rb automatically in sync during migrations == In the file, config/environment.rb, change: 
  # Use SQL instead of Active Record's schema dumper when creating the test database.
  # This is necessary if your schema can't be completely dumped by the schema dumper, 
  # like if you have constraints or database-specific column types
  # config.active_record.schema_format = :sql
To: 
  # Use SQL instead of Active Record's schema dumper when creating the test database.
  # This is necessary if your schema can't be completely dumped by the schema dumper, 
  # like if you have constraints or database-specific column types
  config.active_record.schema_format = :ruby
== Adding a column to an existing table == 
script/generate migration add_creation_date_to_weblogs
class AddCreationDateToWeblogs < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    add_column "weblogs", "created", :datetime
  end

  def self.down
    remove_column "weblogs", "created"
  end
end
rake migrate
= The main controller = 
script/generate controller main welcome
In config/routes.rb 
map.connect '', :controller => 'main', :action => 'welcome'
And delete public/index.html = Creating a scaffold = 
script/generate scaffold weblog
(Accessible at "http://localhost:3000/weblogs/"). = Creating a base layout (used site-wide) = Create a file at app/views/layouts/application.rhtml, indicating where included content should go with <%= @content_for_layout %>. For example: 



	
	<%= @page_title %>


<%= @content_for_layout %>
= See also = * "UsingMigrations": http://wiki.rubyonrails.org/rails/pages/UsingMigrations * "UnderstandingMigrations": http://wiki.rubyonrails.com/rails/pages/UnderstandingMigrations * "Using migrations to evolve your database schema without loosing [sic] your data": http://media.rubyonrails.org/video/migrations.mov * "Using Ruby on Rails for Web Development on Mac OS X": http://developer.apple.com/tools/rubyonrails.html

Many of the articles will be of particular interest to developers although the scope of the [[Knowledge Base]] extends beyond development and even beyond [[Mac OS X]] in many cases. Basically, I try to make a point of recording here useful stuff that I may want to remember in the future. I am making it publicly available because it may be of use to others as well.
Note that the information published here is provided as a free public service without any guarantees or warranties of any kind. I hope that it may prove useful to you but you use this information at your own risk. It is not legal, medical, technical or any other kind of professional advice. See the [[Knowledge_Base:General_disclaimer | disclaimer]] for more details.
This is the new [[wincent.com]] [[Knowledge base]] intended to replace the old Knowledge base at http://wincent.com/a/knowledge-base/. The old Knowledge base was powered by [[Movable Type]] which despite my efforts at organizing things using hierarchical categories was not very well suited to the task (it is, after all, [[weblog]] software). The new Knowledge base is in [[wiki]] format, a much better fit for the task at hand, and uses the same [[MediaWiki]] software that powers [[Wikipedia]].
The plan is that eventually all content will be migrated from the old Knowledge base to the new one. For the time being the content will remain in place at the old [[URL]] and the links on the rest of the site have not yet been updated to point to this [[wiki]].
Useful links:
* [[Special:Search | Search]] (also available from the seach box on the left) * [[Special:Allpages | Index]] (all pages in alphabetical order) * [[Site map]] (articles organized by category) * [[Special:Categories | Categories]] (all categories in alphabetical order)

= Roadmap = * First priority: wiki module (for self-hosting, self-documentation). Given that the plan is to have TextFab be self-hosting, set up two sites: * Stable install: http://textfab.com/ * Bleeding edge/test install: http://trunk.textfab.com/ = Checking out =

Doesn't work gives error: "Before updating scaffolding from new DB schema, try creating a table for your model (User)" 
rake db_schema_dump
Doesn't help 
script/generate model User
Still get error trying to make scaffold customize db/migrate/001_create_users.rb (set up columns, add admin user) customize app/models/user.rb to add password setting code rake migrate (creates table in database and adds admin user with default password) Test that the user was indeed created: 
$ script/console

Now make an admin controller for working with users: script/generate controller Admin And in app/controllers/admin_controller 
class AdminController < ApplicationController
  scaffold :user

page.title: Ruby on Rails: pros and cons

revision.text:
[[Category:Rails]] = Things I like about Ruby on Rails = == Transparent mapping between database tables and models == In general, you don't need to drop down from the level of [[Ruby]] code (to the level of [[SQL]] queries). You query your objects using directly using [[Ruby]] statements and [[Rails]] worries about managing all the database queries for you. The level of [[database abstraction]] is extreme. == Migrations == [[Migrations]] are database agnostic, allowing you to specify your database scheme in [[Ruby]] code rather than using database-specific [[SQL]]. This makes it very easy to, for example, develop locally using [[SQLite]] and deploy remotely using [[MySQL]]. == Incremental/iterative development model == Again thanks to [[migrations]], you can make incremental changes to the database schema as you go without fear of breaking things. You don't have to sit down and design your entire database schema from scratch before you start writing code, and you don't have to worry about making painful changes to the schema down the road (because changes aren't painful). == Testing toolchain == Every application comes with all the testing infrastructure built-in allowing you to do [[test-driven development]]/[[behaviour-driven development]] or at least [[test-enhanced development]]. == It uses Ruby == [[Rails]] is written in [[Ruby]], which delivers: * The [[Object-Oriented]] purity of [[Smalltalk]] * Highly dynamic, like [[Objective-C]] or [[Smalltalk]] * Allows you to write readable, [[natural language]]-like source code * Easy to write quick and powerful functionality in few lines of code (like [[Perl]]) * A clean, predictable, concise and flexible syntax * Not as whitespace-sensitive as [[Python]] * Stable, mature, reliable codebase * Quick and easy to learn * Excellent core documentation: http://www.rubycentral.com/ref/ = Things I don't like about Ruby on Rails = == Inconsistent behaviour of generate controller and generate scaffold== 
script/generate scaffold User
Will produce a controller file named users_controller.rb but: 
script/generate controller User
Will produce a controller file named user_controller.rb. It's still not clear to me how these things should be named. It seems that models should be singular, database tables plural, but controllers? Plural? If so, why does the scaffold command use the plural form and the controller command the singular? Even in published books I note that many of the examples I have use singular controller names and others have plural, but given that the scaffold command creates views with plural names, there is a discrepancy between viewing stuff created with the scaffold command (nicely CSS formatted) and stuff done using a manually generated controller (singular) with a "scaffold :" declaration in the controller. === Answer === From IRC: 
  wincent: plural is conventional but not required like singular models are
 wincent; name the controller BillyBob if you want
  wincent: and yeah, it doesn't have to match up with a model
  wincent: actually script/generate scaffold generates a singular model name. it then pluralizes 
         that model name if no controller name is specified
So the rules of thumb are: # Call your controllers whatever you want # When using generate scaffold, Rails will create a singular model (compulsory) and a plural controller # When using generate controller, Rails will use whatever name you pass in # Therefore for consistency it is a good idea to pass a plural controller name in to generate controller == Documentation shortcomings == In general I find the documentation (http://api.rubyonrails.org/) too hard to navigate, cluttered and overly concise. Some attempts at filling the gaps are available elsewhere: * "[http://www.rails4days.pwp.blueyonder.co.uk/Rails4Days.pdf Four Days on Rails]": http://rails.homelinux.org/ * "[http://blog.invisible.ch/files/rails-reference-1.1.pdf InVisible Ruby On Rails Reference 1.1.2]": http://blog.invisible.ch/2006/05/01/ruby-on-rails-reference/ * "Ruby On Rails–A Cheatsheet": http://www.blainekendall.com/uploads/RubyOnRails-Cheatsheet-BlaineKendall.pdf === How are booleans handled? === As an example, when you declare a table column as having type :boolean, how is that actually stored in the database? Is "true" the number 1? The letter "t"? (Or string?) Or is it "true"? Or "TRUE"? Is it database dependent? All of these questions are left unanswered by the documentation. In my local [[SQLite]]-based setup it appears that true boolean values are stored as the letter "t" when I create a table column as follows: 
t.column :is_superuser, :boolean, :default => false
The [http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Base.html#M000860 documentation for find] has an example which looks a bit like a boolean: 
:conditions => "administrator = 1"
That won't work for me; I instead have to use: 
:conditions => ["administrator = 't'"]
Is there any way of expressing this condition without using database-dependent code? The [http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/ConnectionAdapters/SchemaStatements.html#M000604 documentation for create_table] says nothing; the [http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/ConnectionAdapters/TableDefinition.html#M000659 documentation for column] says only:
The type parameter must be one of the following values: :primary_key, :string, :text, :integer, :float, :datetime, :timestamp, :time, :date, :binary, :boolean.
It provides no further information about these types. If [[Rails]] allows me to create records with :boolean types in a database-indepedent way (eg. User.create :is_superuser => true) what then is the database-independent way of querying based on that boolean? ==== Update: More information on booleans ==== Partial answer: http://wiki.rubyonrails.com/rails/pages/HowtoUseBooleanColumns Definitive answer: http://www.bigbold.com/snippets/posts/show/2086 
:conditions => ['is_superuser = ?', true])
Alternative, prettier answer: "[http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Base.html Dynamic attribute-based finders]": 
User.find_all_by_is_superuser(true)

page.title: Red Hat Enterprise Linux kernel update procedure

revision.text:
[[Category:Red Hat]] For posterity: 
uptime
Check for available updates: 
sudo up2date --list
Echo current release info: 
uname -a
cat /etc/redhat-release
Trigger an update of all non-kernel RPMs: 
sudo up2date --nox -u
Install the new kernel: 
sudo up2date -uf kernel kernel-doc kernel-source kernel-utils
Confirm that the kernel is installed in /boot: 
cd /boot
ll
Check the RPM database: 
rpm -qa | grep kernel
Check that /boot/grub/grub.conf: contains the appropriate lines at position 0 (first in list): 
title Red Hat Enterprise Linux ES (2.4.21-37.0.1.EL)
        root (hd0,0)
        kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.21-37.0.1.EL ro root=/dev/hda3
        initrd /initrd-2.4.21-37.0.1.EL.img
Reboot and cross your fingers: 
sudo reboot
= Post install checks = 
uname -a
cat /etc/redhat-release
Check that critical services are running ([[Bansshee]], FTP, HTTP, MySQL, Mailman, clamd, IMAP, ipop3, [[svn]], [[sendmail]], xinetd, [[webmin]] etc): 
sudo service --status-all
sudo chkconfig --list
See if up2date is now satisfied: 
sudo up2date --list

= Overview = 
app-*-> sites -*-> articles -*-> comments
               |
               *-> weblogs -*-> posts -*-> comments
               |
               *-> forums -*-> topics -*-> posts
               |
               *-> trackers -*-> issues -*-> comments
               |
               *-> wikis -*-> articles -*-> comments
               |
               \-> snippets


users <- memberships -> groups

articles <- categorizations -> categories

tags <- classifications -> entities

entities -> access control lists -> access controls
= Bug reports/feature requests/support tickets = There is no need to have separate systems for support tickets, bug reports and feature requests because they are all really just "issues". Things I like about the MySQL bug tracker: it allows you to type in versions and operating systems instead of selecting from a pop-up menu, requiring less administration (having to update pop-ups). Possible compromise: pop-up + text field for "Other" (possibly expose and update with AJAX, like the WordPress categories thing). A feature from [[FogBugz]] that I'd really like to have is mail-based updating. You should be able to add comments to an issue by replying to an email; special keywords should be able to trigger changes to ticket status. You should even be able to ''open'' a new ticket by sending an email (if the sender doesn't already have an account one will automatically be set up for them and they will be emailed a password). The idea is to have best of both worlds access: easy access via email, but the ability to view the historical record via the web. Not sure if attachments to such emails should be attached to issues. == Models == * Trackers: A site can have multiple issue trackers (although in practice it would be normal for there to be only one). * Issues: A tracker can track multiple issues. * Issue Types/Issue Classes: There are at least three Issue Types/Issue Classes: *# Bug reports: publicly viewable by default *# Feature requests: publicly viewable by default *# Support tickets: private (reporter only) by default * Comments: An issue can have multiple comments * Attachments: An issue can have multiple attachements Only administrators can modify the default characteristics of Issue Types/Classes, create new Types/Classes, or delete Types/Classes. The owner (reporter) of an issue can designate issues as public or private. The owner of a comment can designate it as private (will still be visible by the bug owner though); there is a "cascade" effect. On closing a support ticket (only the owner can mark it as closed/verified) the user will have the option of checking a box to make it public (viewable to other users); in this way the support system can serve as a kind of FAQ database. The administrator must still have the option, however, of not allowing a ticket to be made public ever, in case it contains sensitive information; I guess the best way to express this is to say that a ticket may be made public only if both the owner and the "fixer" say they wish it to be so. = Comments = Given that comments can appear in so many different places in the application, it would be nice to minimise the amount of code duplication. Comments are used in at least the following areas: * Comments on weblog posts * Comments on wiki articles * Comments on tracker issues * Comments on forum posts (although these may be considered "forum posts" rather than comments) * Comments on resources (downloadable files) * Comments on tags (yes, everything should be commentable, although the option should be there to turn off comments) So do we have one Comments class and then make subclasses such as Weblog Comment, Wiki Article Comment and so on? Or do we use a single Comments class and have some kind of polymorphism in place to allow that single model to relate to many different types of classes? Or de we just forget trying to avoid duplication and just have a buch of different comment classes? = Products = Again, a polymorphism question. Products will be able to appear in at least two places: the Resources are and the issue Tracker. It makes sense to share the same model across these sites doesn't it? = Tags = Again polymorphic. Can apply to anything at all, including comments and other tags. = Snippets = Reusable template functionality. Snippets should be accessible anywhere the user can supply text. May need some kind of ownership; ie. users should not be able to use custom snippets authored by other users, nor should they be able to use site-specific snippets made for the admin, but it might be nice if they could use snippets that are intended for sharing by others. Don't ask me to think of an example right now. = Weblogs = * A Site may have multiple Weblogs * A Weblog may have multiple Posts * A Post may have multiple Comments * A Post may belong to multiple Categories * A Category may have mutliple Posts Just need to decide whether Categories are made redundant by Tags. I suspect that Categories are still useful for broad organization, but Tags are good for fine-grained searching and linking across disparate areas of the site. = Forums = * A Site may have multiple Forums * A Forum may have multiple Areas (not sure if that is the best term; alternative: Groups ie. "Groups of Posts") * An Area may have multiple Topics (alternative terms: Posts, Threads) * A Topic may have multiple Comments (or Posts, or Replies; again not sure what the best term is here) = Wiki = Not sure whether the Wiki can be used for general website content (pages, categories etc; think "Content Management System) or whether I should create separate modules for those purposes. I'm inclined to think that a normal website site, the CMS portion, really is just a specialized kind of Wiki (generally read-only, no history visible). Would be good to be able to leverage the wiki stuff for the rest of the CMS aspects. * A Site may have multiple Wikis * A Wiki may have multiple Articles * Articles may contain multiple Snippets * An Article may have multiple Comments * An Article may have multiple Revisions (Revisions are stored as compressed reverse diffs against the following version) * An Article has one revision_number indicating the revision number of the current revision. * An Article has one body containing the text of the current revision. * A Revision has an article_id indicating the article it belongs to. * A Revision has a revision_number indicating the number it occupies in the sequence of revisions. * A Revision has a parent_revision_number indicating the previous revision number. Revisions may be deleted by the superuser (for example, to wipe out all trace of vandalism from the article history); in which case the parent_revision_number is adjusted to skip over the intermediate revisions, the revisions in question are deleted, and the stored diff is updated. In the case of reverting just-perpetrated vandalism the deletion process is a little simpler: the revision is deleted and the article body is reverted. Once again, only the superuser can perform this operation (call it "destroy" instead of "delete"; "deletes" can be "undeleted" but "destroy" operations are irreversible); may wish to add the capability to grant "destroy" privileges to selected users or groups at a later point in time. * An Article has one Owner, the User who first created it; it may be useful to allow additional privileges to Article Owners. A nice feature would be the ability to not only see diffs between the two versions, but also a single page showing the entire history of the page, one diff after another. Diffs can be displayed using CSS spans (strikethrough for deleted, colored background for added).

= Amazon linker = Automatically turns links to books into links to Amazon (optional associate component). The idea is that you should be able to specify a resource locator like an ISBN along with text to be used for the link (eg. a title and/or author name), or in the case where you don't have a resource locator you can just specify title and/or author and you'll get an appropriate search link. = Captcha[http://www.captcha.net/] module = Needn't be too fancy. Multiple ways of implementing a captcha. * Image-based * "Type two large numbers": http://ridiculousfish.com/blog/?p=23 * Do a simple sum (1 + 9, for example) == See also == * http://wiki.rubyonrails.com/rails/pages/HowtoSecureFormsWithNoisyImages = Rating/Feedback module = Note sure if this should be a separate module or built right in to the system. Lots of entity types (especially product pages, for example) would benefit from the ability for the user to indicate whether the article was helpful or not and how it could be improved. Likewise for a simple AJAX-driven star rating system. Could be implemented using a polymorphic relationship (entity_id, entity_type) described in a feedback table. = Caching module = Shield database from hits by writing generated pages out to an on-disk cache. The question is, how to determine when to use the cache, how to identify records in the cache, how to determine when cache records should be marked as stale. = Counter/stats module = At a minimum, record pages views. Potentially record other stats. Edits. = Tagging = Tags can be entered ''en masse'' using a space separator; to enter a tag which includes a space use quotes. = Localization = Localization modules already exist (for example, http://mir.aculo.us/articles/2005/10/03/ruby-on-rails-i18n-revisited) but I'd like a localization module that used the YAML format for the translations files, eg: 
es:
  hello: hola
  buy: comprar
Instead of: 
Localization.define('es') do |l|
  l.store 'hello', 'hola'
  l.store 'buy', 'comprar'
end
If said YAML file could be allowed to include Ruby code (ERb?) like the test/fixtures/model.yml files do, then there would be no down-sides to using this format.

[[Category:Rails]] [[Rails]] argues for "convention over configuration" to minimize time spent by programmers worrying about menial details and maximize time spent on substantive problem solving.
= Model and controller naming conventions =
* Model and class names are singular (<tt>Weblog</tt>, <tt>Post</tt>) and in [[CamelCase]] (<tt>AccessControlList</tt>); if you use <tt>script/generate model</tt> to create a model the class file will be in lowercase, singular, separated by underscores (<tt>weblog.rb</tt>, <tt>post.rb</tt>, <tt>access_control_list.rb</tt>). * Database tables corresponding to models/classes are plural (<tt>weblogs</tt>, <tt>posts</tt>) and in lowercase, separated by underscores (<tt>access_control_lists</tt>). * Controller names are not required to match up with underlying model names, but when they do the convention (not enforced) is to use the plural form of the model name (<tt>WeblogsController</tt>, the corresponding file name would be <tt>weblogs_controller.rb</tt>); if you use <tt>script/generate controller</tt> to create a controller file [[Rails]] will not perform and singular-to-plural conversion but will format the name in lowercase with underscore separators. * If you use <tt>script/generate scaffold</tt> to create a scaffold [[Rails]] will create a singular model file and a plural controller file.
= Database naming conventions =
* Table columns of type <tt>datetime</tt> and named <tt>created_at</tt>/<tt>created_on</tt> or <tt>updated_at</tt>/<tt>updated_on</tt> will be automatically updated by [[Rails]] on record creation and record update respectively. * Table columns named <tt>lock_version</tt> (type: integer, default: 0, null: false) will be used automatically by [[Rails]] to perform "optimistic locking" (an exception will be raised whenever a race occurs). * A column named <tt>counter_cache</tt> can be used to save database lookups (see: http://blog.gorgorg.org/articles/2006/04/04/ruby-on-rails-how-to-actually-use_count-counter_cache).
= Model inheritance conventions =
Given a class hierarchy that looks like this:
* <tt>ActiveRecord::Base</tt> ** <tt>Furniture</tt> **# <tt>Chair</tt> **# <tt>Table</tt>
Rails will expect a single table named <tt>furniture</tt> with a column named <tt>type</tt> that will be used to distinguish which rows are used for the <tt>Chair</tt> model and which for the <tt>Table</tt> model. For more information see:
* http://activerecord.rubyonrails.org/show/SingleTableInheritance * http://rubyonrails.org/api/classes/ActiveRecord/Base.html * http://www.martinfowler.com/eaaCatalog/singleTableInheritance.html
= View conventions =
* If you create a file at <tt>app/views/layouts/application.rhtml</tt> it will automatically be used as a wrapper around all other layouts.

[[Category:Ruby updates]] [[Category:Ruby 1.8.4]] [[Category:Red Hat]] = Note = These notes are superseded by the article, "[[Building and installing Ruby 1.8.5 on Red Hat Enterprise Linux ES 3]]". = Build = 
wget ftp://ftp.ruby-lang.org/pub/ruby/ruby-1.8.4.tar.gz
tar zxvf ruby-1.8.4.tar.gz
cd ruby-1.8.4
./configure
make
make test
sudo make install
make check
= Failed tests = 
  1) Failure:
test_s_open_no_create(TestGDBM) [./gdbm/test_gdbm.rb:94]:
 expected but was
<#>.
The source code for the test_gdbm.rb file notes that: 
# this test is failed on libgdbm 1.8.0
And the version of libgdbm installed on [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]] ES release 3 (Taroon Update 8) is indeed gdbm-1.8.0-20 so I believe the message is probably harmless. 
  2) Failure:
test_verify(OpenSSL::TestX509Store) [./openssl/test_x509store.rb:169]:
This test is expected to be success with OpenSSL 0.9.7c or later.
 expected but was
.

1356 tests, 15391 assertions, 2 failures, 0 errors
make: *** [test-all] Error 1
It's possible that this second test fails because of the version of OpenSSL installed on the server; openssl-0.9.7a-33.17, which is up-to-date with ES release 3 (Taroon Update 8) of [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]]. I believe it is probably a harmless warning, although I can't find any confirmation of that fact on the web. = See also = * [[Building and installing RubyGems 0.9.0 on Red Hat Enterprise Linux ES 3]] * [[Building and installing Ruby 1.8.4 on Mac OS X Tiger]]

= Other gems and engines = Potentially useful gems: * acts_as_taggable: "An acts-as Mixin for easy applying and searching tags/folksnomies on Active Record objects." * fcgi: "FastCGI library for Ruby." * htmltokenizer: "A class to tokenize HTML." * login_generator: "[Rails] Login generator." * mongrel: "A small fast HTTP library and server that runs Rails, Camping, and Nitro apps." * paypal: "Paypal IPN integration library for rails and other web applications." * pdf-writer: "A pure Ruby PDF document creation library." * RedCloth: "RedCloth is a module for using Textile and Markdown in Ruby. = Multi-layered security = [[Ruby]]-level (permissions described in the code). [[MySQL]]-level (permissions described in the database, possibly with [[ACLs]]. == Controller-level security == before_filter == Model-level security == 
attr_accessible
== View-level security == = Access control = I need to decide on an access model. Where does access control belong, architecturally speaking? You can implement some access controller at the model level (ie. raising exceptions for unauthorized access) but then you break encapsulation somewhat (ie. if you inject code into ActiveRecord::Base so that all models have some "knowledge" of your User/Groups/ACL models). Implementing at the model level you have the option of controlling access to creation/deletion methods, and to the setting and getting of specific attributes. Implementing at the controller level you can control access to controller/action pairs. Here is a summary of options for implementing access control: * In the models themselves, at the model level? Access control applied to individual instances of models and/or to meta classes (but where to store the latter? using a foreign id key of 0? are there guarantees that ids will start at 1 on all databases?) * At the controller level? Control based on controller/action pairs? * Access control lists to be stored as models regardless of which approach used here? To illustrate the complexity of the problem, consider this example: * User Fred has a weblog. Only he can make new posts. Anyone can post comments. * User Danny has a weblog. Only he can make new posts. Anyone can post comments, but they are moderated. * User Bill has a weblog. Only he can make new posts. Only Danny and friends can post comments. * User Ray has a wiki. Anyone can post new articles. Anyone can posts comments. * User Jane has an issue tracker. It is private, but Bill (also on her team) can see issues and post comments. * For any given weblog post, the weblog owner may wish to override the default comments permissions. Notice that each weblog can have a different comments policy. Where should the ACL defining default behaviour be attached (to each weblog? as a "post_comment" privilege?). Where should ACL defining overrides be attached? What would the effect of general/meta-class level overrides be (note that by definition these would spread across all weblogs, and across all wikis and issue trackers too in the event that they should share a comments model)? How do privileges "cascade" down (or not) to their children entities (eg. weblogs -> posts -> comments)? If these parent/child relationships are implemented, where and how? (children would have parent_type and parent_id columns -- polymorphic -- and you could attach access controls to those parents which indicated that they were "cascade-down" style privileges? To check the privileges of an entity, query it's parent and check if there are cascade-down privileges, then query parent of parent... wonder if this can be cached; the question of how to "merge" conflicting privileges remains) == Granularity == We can control access at three main levels: === First level access: meta-classes (database tables) === This is the coarsest level of access, in which we can block or grant access to entire database tables at once. Most likely this would be achieved by attaching the Access Control List to "id" 0 (zero) of the table; this should correspond to no real row (if primary key id columns are set to be non-null). === Second level access: model instances (database rows) === This is finer grained access control, in which we block or allow access to a specific instance of a model (a row in the database). This can be achieved by attaching the Access Control List to the appropriate entity (specified using type and id). === Third level access: model attributes (database columns) === This is the finest level of access control, in which we block or allow access to specific columns within the database. There are two variations of this type of access control: # We block/allow access to a specific row in the table for the specified column. # We block/allow access to all rows in the table for the specified column. === How would we model these privileges textually, or in the database? === * Site-wide privileges: entity_id = 0, entity_type = "class_name", privilege = "create/read/update/delete" * Model instance privileges: entity_id = 1, 2, 3 etc, entity_type = "class_name", privilege = "create/read/update/delete" * Attribute level privileges (all rows): entity_id = ?, entity_type = ?, privilege = "create/read/update/delete" * Attribute level privileges (specific row): entity_id = 1, 2, 3 etc, entity_type = "class_name", privilege = "create/read/update/delete;column_name" It's not entirely clear how the privilege should be specified: * using entity_type (to infer class and therefore controller name?) and explicit action? * using entity_type (for class) and explicit controller name and explicit action? The access control may be bound to models at the model level, but access to the models is mediated by the controllers so it's not clear how far the binding should go towards the controllers. Note, it would be bad to break encapsulation and store ACL-related stuff ''inside'' the models, but there is nothing wrong with have ACL tables that are closely tied ''to'' the model tables. The question is, how do we apply this consistently to the entire app? Can we inject methods into all controllers (like in Objective-C)? Should we? Should we inject methods into all models? Should the security extend down to the model level itself (breaking encapsulation somewhat) but with the benefit that programming errors in the controller layer are less likely to expose privileged data? == Access control lists (ACLs) == Every entity has an access control list attached which contains a default set of access declarations. The default values will depend on the class of the entity in question. For example, a Wiki Article will be world-readable/world-editable by default (unless overridden); a support ticket will be private by default, and so forth. ACLs can be of variable length. The relationship between ACLs and entities is polymorphic because entities can be of many different types. The ACL design needs to be able to describe relationships such as the following with a given entity: * User/Group/Role "A" can create/read/update/delete entities (all instances) of class "B" * User/Group/Role "A" can create/read/update/delete this concrete instance of class "B" Need to decide whether the former case (general privileges across all instances of a class) is best handled by being able to explicitly attach an ACL to a "metaclass", or whether it can be handled by setting defaults (not sure where) which apply to all instances of a class. I think I prefer the metaclass option. In terms of models, it seems that the minimum required to implement this is two models: 
script/generate model AccessControlList
script/generate model AccessControl
Using an example entity class, "Sites": 
class Site < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :access_control_list, :as => :entity, :dependent => :destroy
end

class CreateSites < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :sites do |t|
      t.column :name, :string
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :sites
  end
end
class AccessControlList < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :entity, :polymorphic => true
  has_many :access_controls
end

class AccessControl < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :access_control_list
end
class CreateAccessControlLists < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :access_control_lists do |t|
      t.column :entity_id, :integer
      t.column :entity_type, :string
      t.column :created_on, :datetime
      t.column :updated_on, :datetime
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :access_control_lists
  end
end

class CreateAccessControls < ActiveRecord::Migration
  def self.up
    create_table :access_controls do |t|
      t.column :access_control_list_id, :integer
      t.column :created_on, :datetime
      t.column :updated_on, :datetime
    end
  end

  def self.down
    drop_table :access_controls
  end
end
You can then do stuff like: 
s = Site.new
l = AccessControlList.new
s.access_control_list = l
s.save
l.entity # echos the site
# "l.entity = s" also would have worked
c = AccessControl.new
l.access_controls << c
== The superuser == Borrows the concept of the "superuser" from UNIX. The superuser can create/read/update/delete all entities of any kind, bypassing the ACL or any other access control mechanism. == Filesystem comparison == In many ways a web application is like a filesystem. In the following sections I compare the two main ways of approaching filesystem permissions and consider how they might be applied to a web application. === Traditional users and groups permissions === All entities have one owner and one group. The owner and group can be independently set (that is, the owner need not belong to the group, although this is often the case). There are three categories of permissions: owner permissions, group permissions, and permissions for all other users. The filesystem is hierarchical and permissions have a cascade effect. For example, given a pre-existing entity the permissions might be as follows: * The owner can read/write/execute, or any combination thereof. * The group can read/write/execute, or any combination thereof. * All others may read/write/execute, or any combination thereof. In the case of an entity enclosed by another entity, the permissions of the enclosing entity override the enclosed entity's permissions. In other words, in the (admittedly unlikely) case of a file owner by one user being enclosed in a folder owned by another, the enclosing folder could deny access to the file by the files owner. In the case of an entity which doesn't exist yet, it can only be created if the permissions for the proposed enclosing entity are appropriate. === The Highrise model === Highrise allows you to assigned the following privileges: * Everyone can access * Only I can access * This group can... (single) * These people can... (multiple) http://www.highrisehq.com/tour === Goldberg === * http://goldberg.240gl.org/internals * http://goldberg.240gl.org/security === Modern ACL-based permissions === ACLs allow a fine-grained control. Objects may still have owners and groups, but the number of access controls that can be added to an entity is without limit. Likewise, the number of privileges is not limited to just read, write and execute; other privileges might include append, copy, view and so forth. Talking about this in web application terminology, it means the following: * Each entity would have an owner * Generally the entity's owner is its creator, but ownership can be reassigned later on * It is not strictly necessary for an entity to belong to a group, but it may be worth allowing this provided it doesn't complicate the model and supporting code too much * Instead of thinking about things in terms of read/write/execute it is probably more useful to think in terms of create/read/update/delete * In general, owners can grant privileges to other users or groups on items that they own; an owner may not grant privileges beyond those which he himself/she herself possesses (although in some cases it may be desirable to limit the ability of owners to grant privileges; perhaps the right to grant privileges will itself be a special privilege that has to be explicitly awarded by the superuser) * Owners can also renounce their own privileges * Non-owners can not give themselves or anyone else privileges for other entities Consider a small working example: * Start with a weblog * The weblog has an owner (and optionally a group) * The weblog has an access control group containing zero or more access controls * In the absence of access controls, reasonable permissions will apply by default; for example: the weblog owner (and any member of the weblog's group) will have permission to read/update/delete the weblog * These permissions can be supplemented or overridden using the access control list; for example, another user could be granted update access, or the public could be denied read access * Permissions automatically "cascade", so a user with create or update access to the weblog will be able to create a new post "inside" the weblog * Posts made in the weblog inherit the permissions of their parent (the weblog itself) but can be overridden using their ACLs * The superuser can create, read, update or delete anything at all irrespective of permissions * If a user that owns the weblog does not necessarily have the privileges to create other weblogs; in other words, a user can be granted ownership of a weblog but giving them "create" privileges doesn't enable them to actually create other weblogs, it merely allows the "create" privilege to "cascade" down and allow them to make posts on the weblog. It may be possible to employ this "cascading" concept to eliminate the need to worry about "metaclasses". For example, how do you grant the right to create weblogs? What entity would such a right be attached to? To the user? That would break the ACL paradigm given that ACLs are supposed to be attached to entities, not users or groups. Would you need to create a "metaclass" instance to which you could attach an access control? What about the alternative, of having "weblog" instances belong to a "site"? Perhaps you could attach create privileges to the site, allowing a user to create things within the site. Perhaps you need to have a special privilege called "create weblog" (or is that too much of a special case?). Perhaps merely a "create" privilege is enough. So this would require a hierarchy like this: * A (Web) Application ("the" web application) may contain many sites * A Site may contain many Weblogs (or any number of other things) * A Weblog may contain many Posts * A Post may contain Comments If no access control list is defined for an entity, must look to the parent to see if an appropriate access control "cascades" down. Really need to continue looking up the chain until we hit the root (not sure if that should be stored in the database or not, probably in the Parameters table) to be sure that a higher level doesn't block lower-level access (for example, owner of weblog comment should be denied access to the comment if the owner of the weblog later closes all access to the weblog). Most likely will need to implement some sort of caching mechanism to shield the database from excessive queries; and will also need to put a "parent_id" and "parent_class" column in all classes that are going to participate in the cascading. The cache may not be so difficult seeing as all the ACLs are stored in a single table, and all the access controls in another. But the question of how, if and what values cascade may not be straightforward. For example, a weblog owner will have the privilege to create posts but regular visitors will not. Even so, regular visitors might be allowed to post comments. The system needs to be smart enough to know that the lack of a create privilege at the weblog post level should not cascade down and override the create privilege of the visitor at the comment level. For example: * Weblog owners may create posts and comments * Weblog vistors may not create posts but may create comments * Vistors who are not logged in may face a different set of limits A further complication for that example is the question of moderation. It should be possible to either disallow comments for a specific user or group (or for the general class of "non-logged-in users"), allow comments but with moderation, or allow comments without moderation. Ideally there would be a default set of privileges which could be overridden on a per post or per user or per group level. The basic idea is to have reasonable defaults and conventions combined with a strong system of inheritance (for simplicity) but with the power and flexibility necessary for customization and overrides when desired. This in part ties in with the question of instance-level verses class-level access control. Where should the ACL be attached in the general case of "user X has the permission to create objects of class Y" given that no instance of "class Y" is itself an appropriate site for the ACL. Perhaps in this case an ACL with entity_id of zero but entity_type corresponding to the class? Will Rails baulk at that? How to implement the "cascading" aspect? Should the ability to comment on a weblog post be attached to the post, or to the weblog? To the weblog but with optional override in the post? === Soft and hard authorization failures === Of course, it needs to be even finer-grained than this. There should be a distinction between "soft" failures and "hard", blocking failures. * In "soft" failures that view may simply omit the display of data for which a user does not have access * In "hard" or blocking failures the user will be asked for credentials A real world example: in the case of support tickets other users shouldn't even know that they exist. When listing issues in the issue tracker other people's support tickets shouldn't even be listed. But if a user tries to guess a URL and access someone else's support ticket he/she should be stopped with a hard failure. There are really three levels of "read" privilege: # User may see object without special authentication or authorization (for example, a public weblog post) # User is allowed to see evidence that the object exists but may not view the object without authentication and adequate privileges (for example, a protected downloadable resource that requires an appropriate username/password before granting access) # User is not even allowed to see evidence that the object exists (for example, other people's support tickets) Perhaps one way of conceptualizing these levels of access is to take an even finer-grained approach than looking at model-level or action/controller-level security. Consider these scenarios: * User X can see neither the title nor the details of issue A; User X therefore does not even know that issue A exists. * User Y can see the title but not the details; User Y therefore knows that issue A exists but cannot access it. * User Z can see both the title and the details; User Z has full access. == Users and Groups == * A User may belong to many Groups * A Group may contain many Users * A Membership model can be used to encapsulate the User/Group relationship Groups can then be used to specify privileges in some way. A Privileges model may be required (see next section). == Users (and Groups), Roles and Privileges == * A User may have many Roles * A Role may belong to many Users * A Role may have many Privileges * A Privilege may belong to Many Roles * Likewise, Roles can be assigned at the Group level as well (a many-to-many relationship between Roles and Groups) * The Role/Privilege relationship could be encapsulated in a Capability model * The User/Role or Group/Role relationship could also be encapsulated, perhaps again using a Membership model (it may be necessary to distinguish between "Group Membership" and "Role Membership", or find an alternative term) It may be that Users, Roles and Privileges are sufficient. Or Users and Groups. It is not yet clear how this will mesh in with the Access Control List idea. I think Users and Groups is more flexible than Users and Roles because it better matches reality. For example, consider the case in which you create the "weblog editor" role and add users to it. Later on you create another weblog and realise that you want different editors for that weblog. What do you do? Create new role called "Other weblog editor"? It would be better to use Groups all along (groups like "news weblog editors", "products weblog editors"; these group names sound much more natural and a better fit for reality than the Role-based alternatives, because what is the real difference between the "roles" -- that is, the kinds of tasks that people do -- between editors of one weblog and editors of another?), as Roles add nothing to the power of the model, they just change the terminology.

[[Category:Mac OS X]] = First lines of defense (pre-backup) =
== Software RAID ==
== Journaled filesystem ==
[[Apple]] currently (with [[Mac OS X]] [[Tiger]]) provides a journaled filesystem in the form of HFS+, but I have had multiple catastrophic failures of HFS+ volumes, both when used independently and when configured as a software RAID, so I cannot recommend HFS+ for use with any data that you aren't prepared to throw away. HFS+ is effectively a "throwaway filesystem".
In [[Leopard]] Apple will support [[ZFS]] which is a revolutionary filesystem developed by [[Sun]]. It supports journaling, advanced RAID, and unparalleled data integrity verification and self-repair. [[Apple]] has publicly stated that ZFS support will be read-only at first, but we can definitely hope for and look forward to read/write access and bootability from ZFS in the future.

[[Category:Ruby]] Many Ruby methods follow a "bang" pattern to differentiate destructive messages (which alter the object to which they are sent) from non-destructive ones (which do not alter the receiving object).

page.title: Upgrading from WordPress 2.0.3 to 2.0.4 using Subversion

revision.text:
[[Category:WordPress]] [[Category:Subversion]] = Prerequisites = See: [[Preparing WordPress for Subversion-based upgrades]] = For the reckless: the 5 second upgrade = The reckless can perform the upgrade with a single command from inside their [[WordPress]] install. The use of [[sudo]] and the -u user -H options (where you would substitute an appropriate value for user) is to ensure that ownership of the files does not change during the update (necessary if you are running in [[PHP Safe Mode]]): 
sudo -u user -H svn switch http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/tags/2.0.4
A less reckless upgrade procedure is described below, which includes making a backup before upgrading. = For the careful: the 5 minute upgrade = == Check the trunk, branches and tags directories in the repository == Given that in recent versions the [[WordPress]] team hasn't always maintained an [http://wincent.com/a/knowledge-base/archives/2006/06/wordpress_updat.php up-to-date set of tags] in their [[Subversion]] repository, it is a good idea to check that recent changes in the trunk, branches and tags directories on the repository all match up. At the time of [http://wordpress.org/development/2006/07/wordpress-204/ the 2.0.4 release announcement] all three directories appeared to be in sync: * http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/tags/2.0.4/ * http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/branches/2.0/ * http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/trunk/ I checked using the following commands: 
svn log --limit 5 http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/tags/2.0.4
svn log --limit 5 http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/branches/2.0
svn log --limit 5 http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/trunk
And incidentally, using the svn log command (with a higher --limit value) is one way of seeing what changes have been made to the source tree. This is useful seeing as the [[WordPress]] team likes to practise a little bit of [[security through obscurity]], labelling a release as a containing "several important security fixes" but neglecting to mention what they are, nor any of the other "bug fixes (over 50!)" in the release. You can also [http://trac.wordpress.org/query?status=closed&milestone=2.0.4 check the WordPress trac]. == Backup the database == Choosing appropriate values for ${MYSQLUSER}, ${DATABASE} and ${FILENAME}: 
/usr/bin/sudo /usr/bin/mysqldump --opt -u "${MYSQLUSER}" -p -h localhost \
      "${DATABASE}" | /usr/bin/bzip2 -c > "~/${FILENAME}"
== Backup the installed files == If your [[WordPress]] install was in the folder wp you would cd into its parent folder and do something like this: 
/usr/bin/sudo /bin/tar -c -v wp > ~/pre-2.0.4-backup.tar
/bin/gzip --verbose -9 ~/pre-2.0.4-backup.tar
== Disable all plug-ins == http://example.com/wp-admin/plugins.php == Perform the upgrade == Get info on the working copy: 
svn info
Perform the actual upgrade, substituting an appropriate value for ${USER}: 
sudo -u "${USER}" -H svn switch http://svn.automattic.com/wordpress/tags/2.0.4

This failed because of faulty packaging (missing files) in one of the RPMs (see below), but I originally though it was because of changes made to the system in the last major update (see "[[Red Hat kernel-2.4.21-40.EL to kernel-2.4.21-47.EL upgrade notes]]"):
